projectDesc.p: "聲聲慢" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the Tune “Note after Note, Long Song”
Looking and searching,
chilly and clear,
lonesome, dismayed, and desolate.
At the time when it just turned warm yet still quite cold,
it is the hardest for one to rest.
How can two or three cups of weak wine,
shield one from
the harsh wind in the evening.
The wild geese have flown past;
what truly pains the heart,
is that I knew them from the past.
Yellow flowers pile all over the ground,
withered and waned.
Now who would pluck them?
I guard the window,
how do I endure this darkness by myself?
The parasol together with the slight rain,
till the dusk,
dripping and drizzling.
Such circumstance,
how could a single world of “sorrow” suffice!
